Romanians consider themselves a mixture of conquering romans (refering to the 2nd century roman conquest of Dacia by Trajan) and native dacians. They’re well aware however that most of the conquering romans were of celtic, thracian, greek, etc heritage. Here for example is the ‘’origins make-up’’ of the roman auxiliaries in Dacia (ancient Romania), although the numbers for the legions themselves would have been very similar. Romans in Dacia – Balkan Celts  While many were italic, most were a mixture of celtic, thraco-illyrian, semitic, greek, etc So as far as ancestry is concerned, Roman Italy is definetly part of our heritage just like Roman Austria for example, sure. What is most important to note however is that this mixture of invaders (romans) and natives (dacians), resulting in the birth of our people, took place here, in Romania, during ancient times. Not in Italy or anywhere else.

I think Ceausescu once said, “Romanian history begins in Italy”. But he was a delusional dictator, so take from that what you will. The answer is no. The Romanian homeland will always be Romania itself. However, due to cultural, linguistic and historical ties with Italy, we do hold Italy up to a higher standard than other countries. After all, we call ourselves Romanians (a derivative of the Romans), and this etymology ultimately stems from the city of Rome, which happens to be in Italy. So we do think of Italy as a sister nation, even though this sentiment may not be reciprocated by Italians. Notice I said sister nation, not parent nation; this distinction is key because this idealized link to Italy is imbedded in Roman history not Italian history. So Romanians and Italians share more or less a common history through the Roman Empire, but most Romanians do not believe that one country historically supersedes the other.

Just for the fun of it, I remember having read about a 19th century historian, Romanian from Transylvania, named nothing other than August Treboniu Laurian, who wrote a history of Romanians starting manifestly with the foundation of Rome. Following the 18th century Union between a part of the Orthodox Church from Transylvania (constituted mainly by Romanians) with the Catholic Church, there was an amazement of Romanians educated in Rome about the similarities between ancient Latin and the language they spoke. There was only a vague memory of the ancient Roman conquest, but the preservation of such an important cultural affinity in language was received in shock and generated many speculations and naive exaggerations. Among these exaggerations was also this history of Romanians that started with the foundation of Rome. So, to answer your question, at least for some time, at least for some people, Rome was nothing else than the origin of the Romanians. And, let’s face it, no matter how aware we are today that this is a much simplifying myth, many of us are still going to Rome and stare at Emperor Trajan’s column, where the conquest of Dacia is described.

Only culturally, in the very narrow sense the Romanians speak a language derived from Latin. Other than that, the Romanians are the descendants of the Romanized Dacians, just like the Spaniards and the Portuguese are the descendants of the Romanized Iberians and the French are the descendants of the Romanized Gauls. The territory of Romania was colonized mainly with “Romans” from Thracia, therefore DNA evidence shows the Romanians share a considerable number of common genetic ancestors with the Bulgarians from that period of time (2nd-5th century AD). The so-called molecular clock” allows scientists to establish when two genetically related populations stopped intermarrying. In the case of Romanians and Bulgarians, that has happened at the beginning of the 6th century, when the Eastern Roman Empire lost control over Southern Romania because of the arrival of the Slavs.
